reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: Streaming video is well outside my wheelhouse. I know consumer products, insurance, banks and the occasional select industrial, but Netflix belongs to the fast-changing tech/media world with high content costs. I’d rather watch from the sidelines than pretend I understand the long-term game here.  
2. Competitive Moat: While Netflix has scale, high operating margins (32% avg.) and a recognizable brand, content is expensive and competition from Disney, Amazon and HBO is fierce. A moat that requires continual multibillion-dollar content spending is hardly impregnable.  
3. Management & Capital Allocation: Reed Hastings has done a fine job building a subscriber base, but management has leaned heavily on debt (D/E 3.6) and negative owner earnings (–$5/share), signaling capital allocation into content at the expense of free cash flow.  
4. Financial Health & Consistency: A weak ROE of 1.9%, inconsistent earnings growth and no current ratio data worry me. You don’t want to build a business on borrowed dollars when the economy sneezes.  
5. Valuation & Intrinsic Value: A three-stage DCF produces a negative intrinsic value (–$48 raw, –$41 conservative) and margin of safety of –100%. You don’t buy a business if you’d owe money owning it.  
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: The streaming market may consolidate, but heavy content investments, subscriber churn and pricing battles with deep-pocketed competitors create substantial risk.  
7. Opportunity Cost: I’d rather own a steady coke with a modest yield than a volatile streaming giant with negative owner earnings. In my view, NFLX is not a business I’d buy at any price.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 1.9%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.6; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 35.7% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 32.4%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (76.2%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
